title: A Wendy’s near you may be closing soon
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Wendy's plans to close approximately 300 U.S. locations, about 5% to 6% of its restaurants, in 2026.
The closures are part of Wendy's 'Project Fresh' aimed at improving profitability and closing underperforming stores.
Wendy's currently operates over 7,000 restaurants globally, with about 5,600 in the U.S. and 98 in Massachusetts.

title: 6 maps predicting snowfall totals Friday into Saturday
author: John Waller
bullets: Meteorologists forecast 3-6 inches of snow near and north of Route 2, including Merrimack Valley.
Greater Boston expected to receive 1-3 inches of snow due to mixed precipitation on Friday.
Snowfall bands might shift north; updates expected with new data later on Friday.

title: Where to find the best food under $20 in Waltham
author: Katelyn Umholtz and Abby Patkin
bullets: Boston.com highlights top Waltham restaurants serving meals under $20, including Boston Kebab and Carl's Steak Subs.
Recommended dishes include a $15.95 kebab roll-up at Boston Kebab and a $16 cheesesteak special at Carl's Steak Subs.
Other featured eateries include Domenic's for Italian paninis and Guanachapi's for Salvadoran pupusas, all under $20.

title: Turning 40 made her discover running. Ten years later, she’s running Boston.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Melissa Rousselle is running the 2026 Boston Marathon for the Rebekah’s Angels Foundation to mark her 50th birthday.
Rousselle, from Haverhill, began running at 40, using it as an outlet for coping with depression and anxiety.
Rebekah’s Angels Foundation supports children and families affected by trauma, a cause with personal significance to Rousselle.

title: For $3 million, a Newton ‘painted lady’ with plenty of whimsy
author: Megan Johnson
bullets: The Charles Davis House, built in 1860 in Newton Center, is a historic Painted Lady listed for $2,995,000.
The 7,313-square-foot home features six bedrooms, eight-and-a-half bathrooms, and modern amenities with vibrant historic charm.
An additional wing with a private entrance includes a three-room suite, ideal for an office or in-law suite.

title: Could Brian Thomas Jr. be a legitimate trade target for Patriots this offseason?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Brian Thomas Jr. could be a trade target for the Patriots to boost their offense for the 2026 season.
Thomas Jr. had a standout rookie year with Jacksonville, but his production declined in 2025 under head coach Liam Coen.
The Patriots need to upgrade their receiving corps, and Thomas Jr. may offer a dynamic option if available.

title: 3 takeaways from Team USA men’s hockey’s OT win over Sweden in Olympics
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Quinn Hughes scored the overtime winner as Team USA defeated Sweden 2-1 in the 2026 Winter Olympics men's hockey quarterfinals.
Charlie McAvoy, playing without a face shield, delivered significant hits in Team USA's win, logging the third-highest ice time.
Four Boston Bruins, including Hughes and McAvoy, remain in the hunt for Olympic gold, while two Bruins were eliminated with Sweden.

title: Pittsfield armored vehicle company is largest ICE contract in Mass.
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Lenco Industries has secured $5.2 million in ICE contracts for its BearCat armored vehicles, the largest in Massachusetts.
Governor Maura Healey urges companies to avoid ICE contracts, while Lenco continues production with state grants and federal contracts.
Lenco declined $10 million in ICE deals, as their vehicles are also used by military, emergency services, and NATO allies.

title: Former State Police union head, lobbyist get more prison time for fraud, racketeering
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Dana Pullman, former State Police union head, sentenced to two years for racketeering and fraud, must pay $43,915 restitution.
Anne Lynch, former union lobbyist, received 15 months for racketeering and fraud, ordered to pay $41,795 restitution.
Pullman and Lynch misused union funds for personal expenses and kickbacks, involving federal charges of wire fraud and tax evasion.

title: Boston 25 News head meteorologist Kevin Lemanowicz departing after 3 decades with the station
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Kevin Lemanowicz is departing as Boston 25 News chief meteorologist on February 27 after nearly 30 years.
Lemanowicz started at Boston 25 in 1996, covering major Massachusetts storms, including the 2011 tornadoes and 2023 Leominster flooding.
Vice President Todd Brown praised Lemanowicz's dedication while acknowledging his significant impact on New England weather coverage.
